title: Michigan used five-man sledgehammer to take down No. 7 Notre Dame
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg provides his opinion of the top three programs in the history of college football. USA TODAY

Shea Patterson slipped into the background, content to be the supporting actor on this night. He was upstaged by the five large men crouched before him. They go by the names Mayfield, Onwenu, Ruiz, Bredeson and Runyan.

For more than three hours Saturday, they were the star attractions, keeping a soggy but boisterous crowd at Michigan Stadium in their seats and cheering until the final whistle.

Throughout No. 20 Michigan's 45-14 rout of No. 7 Notre Dame, they supplied the horsepower for the Wolverines' offense.

They opened gaping holes, freeing Michigan’s stable of running backs to rip through Notre Dame’s front.

Michigan Wolverines running back Zach Charbonnet celebrates his touchdown with lineman Jon Runyan Jr. against Notre Dame during the first half Saturday, Oct. 26, 2019 at Michigan Stadium in Ann Arbor. (Photo: Kirthmon F. Dozier, Detroit Free Press)

They sealed defenders, allowing the Wolverines to pick up yards in bulk.

They pinned. They pulled. They bulldozed. They conquered.

By the end, Notre Dame had been obliterated, reduced to bits by the Michigan’s five-man sledgehammer.

For those who prefer their Michigan football simple and direct, this brute display of force was a thing of a beauty.

Forget Josh Gattis’ speed in space. The style of offense Saturday was smash-their-face, brought to Brian Kelly’s unsuspecting Notre Dame squad by Michigan’s line coach, Ed Warinner.

Jim Harbaugh's 50-something assistant orchestrated a plan that allowed the Wolverines to overcome the one-loss Fighting Irish and undefeated Mother Nature as they rolled their way to 303 rushing yards.

Patterson, the Wolverines' senior quarterback, didn’t complete a pass until early in the second quarter and instead spent the bulk of his time behind center sticking the ball into the gut of the running back lined up beside him. His right arm, on this night, was not really needed.

By the time he connected with Mike Sainristil for a 13-yard gain that represented the first successful play through the air, the Wolverines had already built a ten-point lead. It would grow soon thereafter, when Patterson scampered 22 yards to the edge of Notre Dame’s end zone and Zach Charbonnet busted through a crowd of bodies as he crossed the goal line.

Right tackle Jalen Mayfield exulted and the Michigan crowd roared, thrilled their team was now ahead, 17-0, as halftime loomed in the distance.

The team that a week before fell three yards short of the end zone in a crushing loss to Penn State found no distance too great to cover.

Seven days after a pass from Patterson slipped through the hands of receiver Ronnie Bell during that defeat's deflating denouement, Michigan showed little interest throwing the ball in any region of the field, at any time during the first 40 minutes of its slugfest with Notre Dame.

Twenty of Michigan’s first 22 plays were runs, as Charbonnet and Hassan Haskins took turns working over Notre Dame’s defense.

The approach, as unbalanced as it was, was sound considering the weather conditions. An 18-mph wind whipped through the stadium as rain soaked the field – conditions that were all but certain to short-circuit the passing offenses attached to Michigan and Notre Dame.

But whereas Michigan adjusted, Notre Dame didn’t. It stubbornly leaned on quarterback Ian Book, who threw the ball on 13 of the Fighting Irish’s 28 plays in the first half and produced only 32 yards through the air during that stretch.

Michigan’s defense, of course, did its part to sully Book’s stat line by consistently invading his pocket and pushing him off his mark.

It was another example of the Wolverines controlling the line of scrimmage and exerting their dominance.

But it was on offense where Michigan showed its true might.

The rushing attack splintered Notre Dame before Patterson broke the Fighting Irish in two when he completed a pair of touchdown passes to Donovan People-Jones and Nico Collins within a seven-minute span that bled from the third quarter into the fourth. After the throw to Collins, Patterson leapt into the arms of one of Michigan's linemen.

Was it Mayfield, Onwenu, Ruiz, Bredeson or Runyan? It didn't really matter because they each earned top billing on a night when Michigan demolishe Notre Dame under the lights.
description: Michigan entered its game against No. 7 Notre Dame with one top 10 win under Jim Harbaugh, but the Wolverines dominated with their offensive line.
